ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned how to write scripts for short plays, dig into my own creativity, and work with others (even if we're not on the same page) to create art.

so it was really cool learning theatre techniques, working with other AMAZING students, and feeling all big drama kid vibes. morning pages can be a great artistic tool or expressive tool for getting out thoughts or emotions, but consistency in this class can be hard. doing the readings can be hard and not always necessary but a lot of them did have interesting lessons.
Devising for theater (creating a piece with a group entirely from scratch). Note that this class is heavily catered to actor-writers.

I learned how to develop an artistic idea from its early stages to a finished product. This course provides you with the creative tools necessary to come up with and execute ideas from the beginning to the completion of the product.

I learned more about it means to collaborate with others, especially in the creative realm (which dives much deeper into the realm of the 
personal than any group academic work).
Techniques to generate creative ideas for scripts and work through long team projects.
Learned a lot about the creative process and collaboration to build week+ long projects

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths: HAL!! what a professor! super relaxed but constructive environment, the morning pages (hot take maybe), the classmates, the guests that pop in
weaknesses: the readings could be updated to reflect a larger range of creatives, including but not limited to queer, disabled, and/or BIPOC.

our class vibes were immaculate and hal cares a lot about students, but for a FYS, i'd say the class was a lot more DRAMA than i expected, so while like he's not grading you like you're an amazing drama person, he has pretty particular tastes for essays and plays sometimes so its not like you'll fail but also it's by no means a gut class. making those plays can be like a part time job but also rewarding when you see the final project. i'd love to see more diversity in the class's guests and readings and conversations.

Strengths: Getting to know other first-years interested in theater. Weaknesses: Unrealistic expectations for what the plays would be, large time commitment around midterm/final, more doing than learning how to do, stressful.
This course's strength was the classmates. I loved acting with them and they truly were the driving force that made this class amazing.

Strengths : Loved Hal-- Professor was amazing and it was always a bright part of my day to go to class. Weakness : Sometimes I wished we did more with the readings, but it was difficult to balance because we did so many activities in class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: i think class guests sometimes were more draining just sitting for two hours but i loved when i got to interact with class mates and do improv activities
I think this class was difficult to begin with over zoom, but the guest speakers was a great addition-- Don't think there was much to be improved through a zoom format.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would highly recommend this course to everyone! I am by no means a theatre/performance studies major, but this class was definitely something that I looked forward to every week. I think that Hal is a wonderful professor and cares deeply about each of his students. I would also do it again just for the shenanigans. I learned a lot about my creative process this year and what it means to work with other people. Also you get to see shows (irl, once this pandemic is over), and that is exciting. I also really loved all the guest artists we met this year!

if you've never tried drama and are okay with like sometimes feeling a lil uncomfy as a POC (hal is lovely but he is a white man, so i think sometimes just subtle differences in understanding occurred and its hard to explain) and like also willing to put some hours into writing a play, then yeah, take it! but also like feel out the class vibes because that is what will make or break the class.

No, unless you really want to take a class in devising in theater (group-made original works) and this is the only course offered during that term. This class was way too stressful, especially for a first-year seminar. It was neither a great introduction to theater for newcomers nor was it an opportunity for experienced theatermakers to grow.

Although I did learn a lot in regards to creativity and collaboration in the theater space, I would not recommend this course for people who engage in theater just for fun (like me). This course takes theater on a more serious note and it requires constant analysis.
Yes! Hal's classes are always organized and fun!

I would! It was a wonderful way to meet students in a remote semester, and learning about the creative process was exactly what I was looking for in this class. Morning pages could be a bit of a handful at times, but ok as long as you don't save them for the last week before they're due.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: we also met outside of class to work on our projects
Weekly modules.
None
